title: VERA FILES FACT CHECK: Robin Padilla misleadingly links Beirut blast to terrorism to justify PH anti-terror law
subtitle: The Lebanese government has yet to establish what exactly caused the explosion of at least 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrates stored in the Port of Beirut.
author: verafiles.org
vclaim:
Actor Robin Padilla, a of President Rodrigo Duterte, justified the enactment of the controversial Anti-Terrorism Act of 2020 by insinuating that the massive port explosion that ravaged Lebanon's capital Beirut was as an act of terrorism.

A day after the , Padilla posted on Instagram a screenshot of about the blast, which damaged multiple properties and killed over 170 people in Beirut, with the caption:

The actor then linked that quoted United States President Donald Trump, who in claiming the explosion appeared to be a "terrible attack."

The Lebanese government has yet to establish what exactly caused the explosion of at least 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrates -- a used to make -- stored in the Port of Beirut.

A day after the explosion, which , the government , led by Lebanese President Michel Aoun with select security and justice officials as members, to investigate and submit a report on the incident within five days, Aug. 11.

The committee was also tasked to identify “negligent” officials in its report to be submitted to court so that “maximum levels of sanctions” may be imposed against those who will be proven responsible. including customs officers, have since been placed under house arrest.

With , Aoun, on Aug. 16, matters related to the blast “are very intertwined and require some time” to investigate. Earlier, on Aug. 11, he signed a decree to the country’s Supreme Judicial Council.

Lebanese officials to the confiscated ammonium nitrates detonated by a fire that razed the Beirut port warehouse where the chemical stockpile was stored. It was kept in the port for six years after a Moldovan-flagged cargo vessel carrying it docked off Beirut in 2013, but held before its crew abandoned the ship, as reported by , , and

Aoun, a former Lebanese army general, the possibility of “external interference by means of a missile or bomb” for the explosion and said he had “personally” asked France (and will ask other countries, if necessary) for aerial photos to determine if there were aircraft or missiles within their airspace at the time of the incident. He, however, dismissed , saying it was a “ .”

The death toll for the explosion has , including ; injured more than 6,000; and left at least 300,000 people homeless. Initial estimates of losses due to the blast is over $15 billion , according to Aoun.

The aftermath also resulted in the of Lebanon’s seven-month-old government led by Prime Minister Hassan Diab and . Diab’s government is serving in a until a .

In the Philippines, have been filed before the Supreme Court against the , which Duterte signed into law on June 5. Petitioners, coming from various sectors, questioned the law’s supposed vague and unconstitutional provisions, such as authorizing an anti-terrorism council to declare a person as a terrorist without court order and prolonging detention without charges from three to as long as 24 days.
